awd_titl_txt: LTREB:  Testing Paradigms About Plant Functional Responses to Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Long-term ecological experiments are needed that simulate the conditions of the future so that scientists can study their potential impacts on ecological communities. This study uses a 20-year old, field experiment, called BioCON, that raises the carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere above prairie plant communities to levels that are expected to occur later in this century. The experiment is designed to study how higher carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere affects the growth of different kinds of plants. The experiment is also designed to understand how the availability of soil nitrogen, an important nutrient that plants need to grow, influences the ability of plants to take up higher levels of carbon dioxide during photosynthesis. Data from the study will be made publicly available through the Cedar Creek, Long Term Ecological Research website. BioCON is visited by over 2500 K-12 students and teachers annually, including teachers of Native American students. College students work and learn how to carry out their own research projects in BioCON each summer. New K-12 lesson plans as well as videos for the sustainability science themed YouTube Channel MinuteEarth will be developed that specifically feature new knowledge gained from BioCON. 

Through continued measurements of functional group and functional group mixture responses to carbon dioxide (CO2) and nitrogen treatments, this study will test two kinds of hypotheses. The first set uses a functional trait classification framework to develop predictions regarding direct functional group responses to eCO2 and N (i.e., responses expected in the absence of soil-mediated feedbacks, species interactions, or interactions with stochastic or directional changes in climate). The second set posits that long-term outcomes will diverge from predictions based on expected direct responses because of modifying processes, involving physiological acclimation, functional group effects on aboveground and belowground resource supply and soil pH, and interactions between treatments and variation in climate. The long-lived perennials in BioCON have not yet equilibrated in their response to CO2 and N, exhibiting interactions with year-to-year variation in climate and generating soil-mediated feedbacks. In BioCON, across 20 years, C4 species have become increasingly productive under high CO2 whereas the benefit of CO2 has gradually disappeared for C3 species, contradicting current theory. Understanding these divergent responses and whether they will continue is a major focus of the study, along with understanding the role of functional groups with respect to other long-term processes relevant to ecosystems under global environmental change, including productivity, decomposition, nutrient cycling, and water fluxes.

por.por_cntn:
In the face of human-caused global environmental change, long-term experiments are needed to replicate future atmospheric chemistry and study their potential impacts on organisms and ecosystems. This study characterized the long-term responses of different plant functional types to elevated CO2 and enriched nitrogen (N) over two decades in the BioCON perennial grassland experiment. The BioCON experiment manipulated CO2, N enrichment, and plant species and functional group composition and richness, and included plots comprising purely C3 grasses, C4 grasses, legumes, or forbs, as well as mixtures of all four types of species, grown under combinations of CO2 and N enrichment.

Functional groups varied in their responses to elevated, but in ways that did not always match predictions based on differences in their biology. Photosynthesis was modestly stimulated by elevated CO2 across all functional groups, and elevated CO2 greatly reduced water loss during photosynthesis. In terms of biomass responses to elevated CO2, species interactions in mixtures amplified responses of functional groups growing on their own. Contrary to expectations based on differences in photosynthetic physiology, elevated CO2 only modestly increased C3 grass biomass and initial positive effects on legume biomass declined or even became negative (at high diversity) over time. Also a surprise – CO2 had a strong positive effect on C4 grasses even though C4 grasses are not typically limited by availability of CO2. Lastly, as expected, forbs showed a positive response to CO2, especially at high diversity levels. Thus continued increases in atmospheric CO2 levels likely will shift the composition of temperate grasslands in favor of C4 grasses and non-legume forbs, and disfavoring C3 grasses and legumes.

Responses to N addition were more consistently aligned with expectations. C3 grasses responded positively to N addition, although this positive effect declined over the duration of the experiment. Legumes tended to be negatively influenced by N addition, especially when grown with other species. C4 grasses showed a diversity-dependent response to N addition: trends of increasing biomass over time were found in 4- and 16-species plots and declining trends were observed for 9-species plots whereas biomass in monocultures did not change much over time. Forbs showed diversity-dependent responses to N addition at both ambient and elevated CO2 levels. At the community level, N stimulation of biomass production diminished over time because N gradually acidified the soils in low-diversity communities and because N caused plant diversity loss in high-diversity communities. Thus, composition of temperate grasslands will be sensitive to future trends in atmospheric N deposition, which have been increasing in many temperate grassland regions.

The modest increased community level biomass under elevated CO2 and added N did not translate into greater soil carbon sequestration. On the other hand, more diverse plots had substantially greater biomass and soil carbon accumulation than species-poor plots. These results suggest that eCO2 will not promote soil carbon storage in these grassland ecosystems and thereby help to slow climate change. However, species richness may influence carbon and N storage more than rising CO2 or soil N supply in perennial grassland systems.

This project helped inform how Earth’s ecosystems will respond to interacting human-caused global environmental changes both through its findings and by contributing data to synthetic meta-analyses conducted by researchers across the globe, in which data from this project were combined with data from similar projects worldwide in new analyses. At the same time, the project trained dozens of undergraduates in how to carry out field ecological research and to conduct independent research, and prepared them for future STEM careers by providing professional development opportunities. The project also supported the training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.
